elements.name: totalK12years
elements.title: How many years have you taught at the K-12 level (any subject)?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number. If you are about to enter your first year teaching, enter 0.

elements.name: csK12Years
elements.title: How many years have you taught COMPUTER SCIENCE at the K-12 level (any subject)?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number. Enter 0 if it's your first year teaching computer science.

elements.name: totalPDTime
elements.title: What is the TOTAL amount of time you have spent on professional development related to computer science or computer science teaching in the last 2 years? (reference: a typical weeklong summer workshop is about 35 hours)

pages.title: Teaching Context
pages.description: First, we have some questions about the context in which you are teaching {workshopCourse}. Your responses help us understand issues that may be unique to your local context and allow us to develop programming to provide you with support.

elements.name: teachingCSMatrix
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about teaching computer science?
rows: I am committed to teaching computer science.
I like, or think I will like, teaching computer science.
I understand computer science concepts well enough to be an effective teacher of computer science.
I have the skills necessary to be an effective teacher of computer science.

elements.name: csCommunityMatrix
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your computer science teaching community?
rows: I feel connected to a community of computer science teachers.
When I need help teaching computer science I have someone to turn to.
I know computer science teacher leaders and role models in my community.
I feel like I'm part of a broad computer science education movement.
I see my Regional Partner as a hub of resources and support for computer science education in my community.

elements.name: successfulCSMatrix
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following? I believe a successful computer science teacher…
rows: ensures that students work collaboratively when writing code.
creates a classroom culture in which students regularly get feedback on their work from their peers.
ensures that every student has a daily opportunity to share ideas and be heard by classmates through partnered conversations and/or small-group or large-group discussion.
creates a culture in which problems or failures are normalized and welcomed as a natural part of the problem solving process.
provides frequent opportunities for students to do reflective writing as a way to promote sense-making and self-expression.

elements.name: Select the option that you agree with the most:
choices: All students should be required to take a computer science course
Some students should be required to take computer science as part of a specialized pathway
Computer science should be integrated into existing required courses
Computer science should be offered to all students as an elective

elements.name: identityImpactMatrix
elements.title: What is your perspective about how your identity, especially with regards to your gender or race, impacts how you teach?
rows: I believe my race affects how I teach.
I believe the race of my students affects how I teach.
I believe my gender affects how I teach
I believe the gender of my students affects how I teach.

pages.name: Your Concerns About Teaching {workshopCourse}

elements.name: rating description
elements.html:
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now Somewhat true of me now Very true of me now

elements.name: concerns
elements.title: Concerns about {workshopCourse} right now.
rows: I would like to know where to find all the Code.org course materials and resources I need.
I am concerned about the amount of time needed to cover all the material.
I am concerned about my own computer science content knowledge.
I would like to develop working relationships with other teachers who are teaching this course.
I am concerned about my inability to manage all that teaching this course requires.

elements.name: question2
elements.html:
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now Somewhat true of me now Very true of me now

elements.name: question3
elements.title: Concerns about {workshopCourse} right now. (continued)
rows: I am concerned about the variety of technology I need to teach the course.
I am concerned about having enough support for teaching computer science. (i.e., from district, school, principal, community, parents, etc.)
I would like to determine how to supplement, enhance, or replace Code.org course materials with other curriculum or CS content.
I am concerned about my class being fully enrolled (or recruiting students into the class).
I am concerned about how well this course will work for my students.

elements.name: other concerns
elements.title: If you have other concerns you'd like us to know about, please provide details here.

pages.title: Your Concerns About Teaching {workshopCourse}
pages.description:
The following items help us determine what you are concerned about at various times during the process of adopting the {workshopCourse} curriculum.

We use this to better understand your personal needs and concerns through your development.

The items below are intended to span a range of things a {workshopCourse} teacher might be concerned about regardless of prior experience.  Thus, many of the items below may appear to be of little relevance to you at this time.  For irrelevant items, mark your response as "N/A". For others, mark the intensity of your concern across a 7 point scale. 

Please respond to the items in terms of your present concerns, or how you feel about your involvement with {workshopCourse} right now.

pages.name: Teaching Practices

elements.name: selfAssessmentRatings
elements.html:
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now
not well prepared, need more development 		Somewhat true of me now
somewhat prepared, in process developing 		Very true of me now
well prepared, current strengths

elements.name: question4
elements.html: As before, please respond based on your sense of preparation and development right now.  We use your responses to understand where and how you want to develop as a teacher.

elements.name: teachingInGeneral
elements.title: Teaching computer science in general. Right now...
rows: I know how to formally assess students’ learning and performance in computer science.
I have strategies to recruit students into my computer science class.
I have strategies to retain students in my computer science class.

elements.name: selfAssessmentRatings2
elements.html:
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now
not well prepared, need more development 		Somewhat true of me now
somewhat prepared, in process developing 		Very true of me now
well prepared, current strengths

elements.name: canDoNowCSP
elements.title: Please indicate the degree to which you think you could do the following things right now.
rows: Create a computational artifact using computing tools and techniques to solve a problem.
Develop an abstraction when writing a program or creating other computational artifacts.
Extract information from data to discover and explain connections or trends.
Express an algorithm in a language.
Develop a program for creative expression, to satisfy personal curiosity, or to create new knowledge.
Explain the abstractions in the Internet and how the Internet functions.
Analyze the beneficial and harmful effects of computing.

elements.name: canDoNowCSD
elements.title: Please indicate the degree to which you think you could do the following things right now.
rows: Use a structured problem solving process to iteratively improve a project.
Develop a program for creative expression, to satisfy personal curiosity, or to create new knowledge.
Make responsible decisions as both a creator and consumer of public content, considering the needs and rights of others.
Explain the differences between how humans and computers approach problems.
Explain the beneficial and harmful effects of computing.

elements.name: selfAssessmentRatings3
elements.html:
Previously, we asked you whether you believe successful computer science teachers use certain practices in their classrooms. Now we ask you to use the "true of me now" scale to think about your own development and the degree to which you believe you have concrete teaching strategies for engaging with those practices yourself. A concrete strategy is a specific teaching technique, method, or named practice that you could describe or demonstrate to another teacher right now, if asked.
 
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now
not well prepared, need more development 		Somewhat true of me now
somewhat prepared, in process developing 		Very true of me now
well prepared, current strengths

elements.name: concreteStrategies
elements.title: Right now, I have concrete teaching strategies to...
rows: ensure that students work collaboratively when writing code.
create a classroom culture in which students regularly get feedback on their work from their peers.
ensure that every student has a daily opportunity to share ideas and be heard by classmates through partnered conversations, small-group or large-group discussion.
create a culture in which problems or failures are normalized and welcomed as a natural part of the problem solving process.
provide frequent opportunities for students to do reflective writing as a way to promote sense-making and self-expression.

pages.title: Self-assessment of Computer Science Knowledge & Teaching Practices
pages.description:
Whether you are new to teaching computer science or a seasoned veteran, you have certain expectations about what kinds of teaching strategies computer science teachers use with students in classrooms.

We'll use the "true of me now" scale used previously to have you self-assess your current knowledge and skills teaching computer science. Instead of concerns, please think about how true it is that you can do certain things in terms of your own development and preparation for teaching computer science.

elements.name: question1
elements.html: Below are pairs of statements from computer science teachers describing various philosophies or approaches to teaching, presented as Statement A and Statement B like so:

elements.name: statementAB
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
... ...

elements.name: question6
elements.html: Please select the value 1-5 that best shows how closely your own beliefs are to one of the statements in a given pair. Please respond freely based on your personal beliefs and philosophy - there is no right or wrong way to respond.

elements.name: statementABExpertise
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
"I do not need to have deep expertise in computer science in order to successfully teach it. I have expertise in how to learn, and I can model that for my students as we learn the content together." "As the teacher, I need to have deep content expertise so that I can properly answer students’ questions and guide instruction appropriately."

elements.name: instructionStatements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
"For computer science instruction, I think it’s important to present students with appropriate terms and vocabulary before they explore a concept or problem in more depth." "I like to present students with a computer science problem, or with tools that let them explore a concept before teaching the terms and vocabulary."

elements.name: recruitingStatements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
Computer science teachers’ responsibility is to promote their computer science classes broadly, to all students. The diversity of the class will reflect those most interested in taking a computer science class. Computer science teachers have a responsibility to recruit a set of students into their classrooms that are representative of the school’s population in terms of diversity (gender, racial, socio-economic, etc.)

elements.name: question5
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
It’s important that the teacher prioritize their time and resources for students who have the most need. The teacher should ensure that their time, and students’ access to resources are distributed equally for all.

elements.name: materialStatements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
Instruction and class activities should focus on maintaining high standards and rigor so that students reach the highest level of achievement, even if some students struggle with the material. Instruction and class activities should focus on ensuring that students with the least prior knowledge and preparation are not left behind, even if that means that less material can be covered.

elements.name: highestLevelEducation
elements.title: Which most accurately describes the highest level of formal computer science education you have completed?
choices: At this time, I have little to no formal education in computer science.
I have taken one or more courses online for credit.
I took one or more courses in college.
I am currently in the process of earning a computer science degree.
I have a Bachelor's degree in computer science.
I have a Master's degree in computer science.
I have a PhD in computer science.

elements.name: teachingPlan
elements.title: Which of the following most closely applies to you about teaching {workshopCourse} next school year:
choices: I was assigned to teach the course.
I chose to teach the course.
I am not currently planning to teach the course next year.

elements.name: birthYear
elements.title: What is your year of birth?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number e.g. 1975.

elements.name: genderIdentity
elements.title: What is your gender identity?
choices: Female
Male
Non-binary
Preferred term not listed
Prefer not to answer

elements.name: racialEthnicIdentity
elements.title: What is your racial or ethnic identity? [check all that apply]
choices: American Indian/Alaska Native
Asian
Black or African American
Hispanic or Latino
Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander
White
Other

elements.name: question7
elements.html:
Thank you!

Thank you so much for taking the time to complete this survey. Your input and feedback is vital for our programs.
